text: Solve this problem step by step.
End with 'DONE.' when you have a solution.
Question: A gardener wants to determine if a new fertilizer increases tomato plant growth.
She has 10 tomato seedlings of the same variety that she planted on the same day.

Design an experiment to test the effectiveness of the fertilizer, explaining what the control variables should be, what the experimental variable is, and how to set up a proper control group for comparison.

Solution: 
<think>
Okay, so the gardener wants to figure out if a new fertilizer is making her tomato plants grow better.
She has 10 seedlings, same variety, planted on the same day.
Hmm, I need to design an experiment here.
First, I should think about what variables are involved.
The main thing she wants to see is if the fertilizer affects growth.
So, the experimental variable is probably the type of fertilizer used.
She has a control group, which is the standard fertilizer, and the treatment group gets the new one.
But wait, what about the control variables? Those are the things that shouldn't change between the groups.
Like, the soil type should be the same for all plants.
If she changes the soil, that could affect growth regardless of the fertilizer.
So, all plants should be in the same soil.
Also, sunlight, water, and temperature are important for plants.
She needs to make sure all seedlings get the same amount of sunlight, watered equally, and kept at the same temperature.
Otherwise, any differences in those could mess up the results.
Now, how to set up the control group.
She has 10 plants.
Maybe divide them into two groups of 5.
One group gets the new fertilizer, the other gets the regular one.
That way, any differences can be measured between the two.
For measuring growth, she could record the height and number of leaves at the start and after a certain time, like a month.
That way, she can see if the new fertilizer made them grow more.
Wait, should she randomize which plants get which fertilizer? Yeah, that makes sense.
Otherwise, she might accidentally give the better plants to one group without knowing.
Also, she should use identical pots or planters for all, same size, same drainage.
That way, the only difference is the fertilizer.
So, in summary, the control variables are soil, water, sunlight, and temperature.
The experimental variable is the fertilizer type.
Control group uses regular fertilizer, and the treatment group gets the new one.
She measures growth after some time, like a month, and compares the two groups.

</think>

The gardener should design an experiment with two groups of 5 tomato seedlings each.
Both groups will be planted in identical pots in the same soil, exposed to the same sunlight, watered equally, and maintained at the same temperature.
One group will receive the new fertilizer, while the control group will receive the standard fertilizer.
Growth will be measured by recording the height and number of leaves after a month.
This setup ensures that only the fertilizer is the variable, providing clear data on its effectiveness.
